bonus.title: Bonus Calculator
bonus.description: Calculate employee bonuses based on base salary, bonus percentage, and performance factor.

inputs.bonus_percentage_tooltip: Target bonus as percentage of base salary
inputs.performance_factor_tooltip: Multiplier based on performance (1.0 = meets expectations)

howItWorks.title: How Bonus Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Bonus = Base Salary × (Target Bonus % / 100) × Performance Factor
howItWorks.explanation: Performance bonuses are calculated as a percentage of base salary, adjusted by a performance multiplier. Target bonus represents expected payout for meeting expectations; the performance factor scales this up or down based on actual performance.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter your annual base salary

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Input your target bonus percentage (stated in offer letter)

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Specify the performance factor based on your review

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Calculator applies performance factor to target bonus

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: View actual bonus amount and total compensation

useCases.title: Bonus Estimation
useCases.description: Estimate expected bonus payout based on your performance rating before official announcement.

useCases.title: Job Offer Comparison
useCases.description: Compare total compensation across job offers with different base salaries and bonus structures.

useCases.title: Performance Goal Setting
useCases.description: Understand bonus implications of different performance levels to set appropriate goals.

useCases.title: Financial Planning
useCases.description: Plan finances and budgets by understanding expected bonus timing and amounts.

seoTips: Typical target bonuses: Entry-level 5-10%, Mid-level 10-20%, Senior 20-40%, Executive 50%+
Performance factors usually range from 0% (no bonus) to 150-200% for top performers
Bonus is typically paid annually, but some companies pay quarterly
Company performance often affects bonus pool independently of individual performance
Signing bonuses and spot bonuses are separate from annual performance bonuses

commonMistakes.title: Assuming Bonus is Guaranteed
commonMistakes.description: Discretionary bonuses depend on company and individual performance. Budget based on base salary, not expected bonus.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Tax Impact
commonMistakes.description: Bonuses are often withheld at a higher rate (22% federal supplemental rate) though total tax is the same as regular income.

commonMistakes.title: Not Understanding Performance Criteria
commonMistakes.description: Clarify how performance is evaluated and what factors determine the multiplier. Subjective vs. objective criteria matter.

commonMistakes.title: Overlooking Company Performance Component
commonMistakes.description: Many bonus structures include company-wide performance factors. Strong personal performance with poor company results may still yield reduced bonus.

faqs.question: What is a typical performance bonus?
faqs.answer: Varies by role and company. Entry-level: 5-10% of salary. Manager: 15-25%. Director/VP: 25-50%. Executive: 50-100%+.

faqs.question: When are bonuses typically paid?
faqs.answer: Most commonly Q1 of the following year (January-March). Some companies pay quarterly or upon project completion.

faqs.question: Are bonuses taxed higher than salary?
faqs.answer: Same tax rate, but federal withholding uses 22% supplemental rate. You may owe more or get a refund at tax time.

faqs.question: What if I leave before bonus payout?
faqs.answer: Depends on company policy. Many require employment on payout date. Some prorate for partial year. Check your employment agreement.

faqs.question: How can I maximize my bonus?
faqs.answer: Understand evaluation criteria, document achievements, align with company goals, and have performance discussions before review time.

salary.title: Salary Calculator
salary.description: Convert salary between different pay frequencies - annual, monthly, bi-weekly, weekly, and hourly rates.

inputs.salary_tooltip: Enter your salary in any frequency
inputs.pay_frequency_tooltip: How often you receive your pay

results.note: Calculations assume standard work week. Actual take-home pay may vary based on taxes, benefits, and deductions.

info.title: About Salary Calculator
info.use_case_1: Compare job offers with different pay structures
info.use_case_2: Budget planning based on pay schedule

howItWorks.title: How Salary Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Annual Salary = Hourly Rate × Hours Per Week × Weeks Per Year
howItWorks.explanation: The salary calculator converts compensation between different pay frequencies: annual, monthly, bi-weekly, weekly, and hourly. It accounts for work hours and weeks to provide accurate conversions for comparing job offers or budgeting.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter your salary amount in any frequency

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Select the pay frequency (annual, monthly, hourly, etc.)

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Specify hours per week if converting to/from hourly

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Enter weeks worked per year (typically 52)

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Calculator converts to all other pay frequencies

useCases.title: Job Offer Comparison
useCases.description: Convert salaries to the same frequency to compare offers - one quoted annually vs. one quoted hourly.

useCases.title: Budget Planning
useCases.description: Understand your monthly or bi-weekly take-home for budgeting based on annual salary figures.

useCases.title: Salary Negotiation
useCases.description: Convert your desired annual salary to hourly rate for contractor negotiations, or vice versa.

useCases.title: Freelance Pricing
useCases.description: Determine hourly rate needed to match a target annual income considering billable hours.

seoTips: Standard full-time is 40 hours/week, 52 weeks/year = 2,080 hours annually
Account for unpaid time off when converting - 50 weeks may be more realistic than 52
Gross salary differs from net (take-home) - factor in taxes and deductions
Benefits have value too - healthcare, 401k match add to total compensation
Bi-weekly pay means 26 paychecks/year, not 24 (important for budgeting)

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting Benefits Value
commonMistakes.description: A lower salary with good benefits (health insurance, 401k match) may exceed a higher salary without benefits in total value.

commonMistakes.title: Confusing Bi-Weekly and Semi-Monthly
commonMistakes.description: Bi-weekly is every 2 weeks (26 pay periods). Semi-monthly is twice per month (24 periods). The difference adds up.

commonMistakes.title: Not Accounting for Taxes
commonMistakes.description: Gross salary isn't what you take home. Factor in federal, state, local taxes and deductions for realistic budgeting.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Overtime Eligibility
commonMistakes.description: Salaried employees may be exempt from overtime. Hourly workers earning overtime may exceed comparable salaries.

faqs.question: How do I convert annual salary to hourly?
faqs.answer: Divide annual salary by total work hours. For standard full-time: Annual / 2,080 hours. $52,000 / 2,080 = $25/hour.

faqs.question: Is bi-weekly the same as twice a month?
faqs.answer: No. Bi-weekly is every 2 weeks (26 paychecks/year). Semi-monthly is twice per month (24 paychecks/year). Bi-weekly pays slightly more over a year.

faqs.question: What's considered a good salary?
faqs.answer: Depends on location and industry. US median is about $60,000. Consider cost of living - $80K in NYC may equal $50K in the Midwest.

faqs.question: How do I account for unpaid time off?
faqs.answer: Reduce weeks per year. If you take 2 weeks unpaid vacation, use 50 weeks instead of 52 for more accurate hourly conversion.

faqs.question: Should I include bonuses in salary calculations?
faqs.answer: For budgeting, use base salary only since bonuses aren't guaranteed. For total compensation comparison, include expected bonuses.

hourly_wage.title: Hourly Wage Calculator
hourly_wage.description: Convert annual salary to hourly wage and calculate earnings across different time periods.

inputs.annual_salary_tooltip: Your total yearly salary before taxes

results.formula: Hourly Rate = Annual Salary / (Hours Per Week × Weeks Per Year)

info.title: About Hourly Wage Calculator
info.use_case_1: Determine true hourly value of salary

howItWorks.title: How Hourly Wage Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Hourly Rate = Annual Salary / (Hours Per Week × Weeks Per Year)
howItWorks.explanation: Converting annual salary to hourly rate reveals true earning power per hour worked. This is essential for comparing salaried positions to hourly jobs, calculating freelance rates, or understanding the value of your time.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter your annual salary (gross, before taxes)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Input standard hours worked per week (typically 40)

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Specify weeks worked per year (52, or less for unpaid time off)

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Calculator divides salary by total annual hours

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: View hourly rate and breakdowns by day, week, and month

useCases.title: Salary to Hourly Comparison
useCases.description: Compare a salaried job offer to an hourly position by converting both to the same unit.

useCases.title: Freelance Rate Setting
useCases.description: Determine minimum hourly rate needed as a freelancer to match current salary, accounting for self-employment costs.

useCases.title: Overtime Valuation
useCases.description: Understand what your time is worth when deciding whether to work extra unpaid hours.

useCases.title: Side Job Evaluation
useCases.description: Compare side gig hourly rates to your main job's effective hourly rate.

seoTips: Standard calculation uses 2,080 hours (40 hours × 52 weeks)
For freelancing, add 30-40% to account for self-employment taxes and benefits
Consider actual hours worked, not just scheduled hours, for true rate
Include unpaid overtime for realistic comparison between jobs
Factor in commute time for total time cost of employment

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Unpaid Work
commonMistakes.description: Many salaried employees work beyond 40 hours. Include actual hours worked for true hourly rate.

commonMistakes.title: Not Adjusting for Benefits
commonMistakes.description: When comparing to freelance work, add 25-40% to cover healthcare, retirement, and self-employment taxes you'd pay.

commonMistakes.title: Using Wrong Weeks Per Year
commonMistakes.description: If you have unpaid vacation time, reduce weeks accordingly. Using 52 weeks overstates hourly rate.

commonMistakes.title: Comparing Gross to Net
commonMistakes.description: Ensure you're comparing like to like - both gross or both net. Mixing leads to inaccurate comparisons.

faqs.question: How many work hours are in a year?
faqs.answer: Standard full-time is 2,080 hours (40 hours × 52 weeks). Excluding vacation and holidays: 1,920-2,000 hours is more realistic.

faqs.question: What's a good hourly rate?
faqs.answer: Depends on industry and location. US average is about $30/hour. Tech and specialized fields can be $50-150+/hour.

faqs.question: How do I set freelance rates from salary?
faqs.answer: Take your hourly equivalent and add 30-50% for self-employment taxes, healthcare, retirement, equipment, and downtime between projects.

faqs.question: Should I include bonuses in the calculation?
faqs.answer: For guaranteed bonuses, yes. For performance-based bonuses, calculate both with and without for range. Don't include uncertain income.

faqs.question: Is hourly or salary better?
faqs.answer: Depends on circumstances. Hourly guarantees payment for all hours worked including overtime. Salary offers stability but may mean unpaid overtime.

overtime.title: Overtime Calculator
overtime.description: Calculate overtime pay based on regular hours, overtime hours, and pay multipliers.

inputs.overtime_hours_tooltip: Extra hours worked beyond regular schedule
inputs.overtime_multiplier_tooltip: OT pay rate multiplier (e.g., 1.5 for time-and-a-half)

errors.hours_too_high: Total hours cannot exceed 168 per week

results.formula: Total Pay = (Regular Hours × Rate) + (OT Hours × Rate × Multiplier)

info.title: About Overtime Calculator
info.use_case_3: Plan work schedule for income goals

howItWorks.title: How Overtime Pay Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Total Pay = (Regular Hours × Rate) + (Overtime Hours × Rate × Multiplier)
howItWorks.explanation: Overtime pay compensates workers for hours beyond the standard work week, typically 40 hours in the US. The Fair Labor Standards Act requires non-exempt employees receive at least 1.5x their regular rate for overtime hours.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter your regular hours (usually up to 40)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Input overtime hours worked beyond regular schedule

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Enter your standard hourly rate

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Select overtime multiplier (typically 1.5x)

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Calculator computes regular pay, overtime pay, and total

useCases.title: Paycheck Verification
useCases.description: Verify that your employer has correctly calculated overtime pay on your paycheck.

useCases.title: Income Planning
useCases.description: Calculate potential earnings when considering overtime opportunities to meet financial goals.

useCases.title: Employer Budgeting
useCases.description: Estimate labor costs including overtime for project staffing and budget planning.

useCases.title: Schedule Optimization
useCases.description: Determine optimal work schedule to maximize earnings within legal and personal limits.

seoTips: FLSA requires 1.5x pay for hours over 40/week for non-exempt employees
Some states (California) require daily overtime after 8 hours
Salaried employees may be exempt from overtime depending on duties and salary
Double time is often required for hours over 60/week or on holidays
Keep records of all hours worked to ensure proper overtime compensation

commonMistakes.title: Not Knowing Exemption Status
commonMistakes.description: Many employees misunderstand whether they're exempt or non-exempt. Salary alone doesn't determine exemption - job duties matter.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring State Laws
commonMistakes.description: Some states have stricter overtime laws than federal FLSA. California requires daily overtime; some states have no overtime laws.

commonMistakes.title: Calculating on Wrong Base Rate
commonMistakes.description: Overtime should be calculated on the regular rate of pay including shift differentials and some bonuses, not just base rate.

commonMistakes.title: Averaging Hours Across Weeks
commonMistakes.description: Overtime is calculated weekly, not averaged. Working 50 hours one week and 30 the next still requires OT pay for the 50-hour week.

faqs.question: Who is entitled to overtime pay?
faqs.answer: Non-exempt employees working over 40 hours/week. Exemptions apply to some salaried professionals, executives, and administrators based on job duties.

faqs.question: What is time and a half?
faqs.answer: 1.5 times your regular hourly rate. If you earn $20/hour, time and a half is $30/hour for overtime hours.

faqs.question: Can my employer force overtime?
faqs.answer: Generally yes, employers can require overtime as a condition of employment, subject to labor laws and union agreements.

faqs.question: Is overtime taxed differently?
faqs.answer: Overtime is taxed at your normal income rate. It may seem higher due to withholding, but annual tax is the same rate.

faqs.question: What is double time?
faqs.answer: 2x regular pay, required in some states (California) for hours over 12/day or work on the 7th consecutive day.

commission.title: Commission Calculator

info.title: About Commission
info.description: Commission is a fee paid to an agent or employee for transacting a piece of business or performing a service.

howItWorks.title: How Commission Calculation Works
howItWorks.explanation: Commission compensates salespeople based on their sales performance. It can be the sole compensation (straight commission) or combined with a base salary. Total earnings equal base salary plus commission earned.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter the total sales amount generated

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Input the commission rate percentage

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Optionally add a base salary amount

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Calculator computes the commission earned

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: View total earnings (base + commission)

useCases.title: Sales Compensation
useCases.description: Calculate earnings for sales representatives based on their closed deals and commission structure.

useCases.title: Real Estate Transactions
useCases.description: Determine agent commissions on property sales, typically ranging from 2.5% to 6% of sale price.

useCases.title: Affiliate Marketing
useCases.description: Calculate earnings from affiliate sales and referrals based on agreed commission percentages.

useCases.title: Recruiter Fees
useCases.description: Compute placement fees for recruiters, often 15-25% of the placed candidate's first-year salary.

seoTips: Understand your commission structure - flat rate, tiered, or graduated
Track sales and commissions separately for accurate income planning
Consider how returns and cancellations affect commission (chargebacks)
Factor in commission caps if your plan has maximum earnings limits
Calculate effective hourly rate to compare commission vs salaried positions

commonMistakes.title: Not Accounting for Taxes
commonMistakes.description: Commission income is fully taxable. Set aside 25-35% for taxes to avoid surprises at tax time.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Commission Splits
commonMistakes.description: In team sales or brokerage, commissions may be split. Calculate your actual share, not gross commission.

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting Clawbacks
commonMistakes.description: Some commission plans require payback if customers cancel or return. Track potential clawback exposure.

commonMistakes.title: Miscalculating Tiered Rates
commonMistakes.description: Tiered commission structures pay different rates at different levels. Calculate each tier separately, don't apply top rate to all sales.

faqs.question: What is a typical sales commission rate?
faqs.answer: Varies by industry: Real estate 2.5-6%, Car sales $100-500 per vehicle, SaaS 10-20% of contract value, Retail 1-10%, Insurance 5-20% first year.

faqs.question: What's the difference between draw and commission?
faqs.answer: A draw is an advance against future commissions, providing steady income. You must earn enough commission to 'pay back' the draw before earning additional commission.

faqs.question: How do tiered commissions work?
faqs.answer: You earn different rates at different sales levels. Example: 5% on first $50K, 7% on $50K-100K, 10% above $100K. Higher sales unlock higher rates.

faqs.question: Should I choose salary + commission or straight commission?
faqs.answer: Straight commission offers higher earning potential but more risk. Base + commission provides stability. Consider your industry, experience, and risk tolerance.

faqs.question: When is commission typically paid?
faqs.answer: Usually monthly or bi-weekly. Some companies pay upon deal close, others upon customer payment. Understand your company's commission payment cycle.

labor_cost.title: Labor Cost Calculator
labor_cost.description: Calculate total labor costs including wages, hours, benefits, and overhead.
labor_cost.benefits_percentage_tooltip: Benefits as percentage of wages (health, retirement, taxes)
labor_cost.overhead_percentage_tooltip: Administrative and operational costs as percentage of wages

errors.invalid_benefits: Benefits percentage must be between 0 and 200
errors.invalid_overhead: Overhead percentage must be between 0 and 200
errors.invalid_employees: Number of employees must be at least 1

results.formula_desc: Total = Rate × Hours × (1 + Benefits% + Overhead%) × Employees

howItWorks.title: How Labor Cost Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Total Labor Cost = Wages + Benefits + Overhead
howItWorks.explanation: True labor cost extends far beyond base wages. Benefits (healthcare, retirement, paid time off) typically add 20-40% to wages. Overhead (workspace, equipment, management) adds another 10-30%. The effective hourly rate can be 1.5-2x the base wage.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter base hourly rate for employees

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Input hours worked per week

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Add benefits percentage (healthcare, PTO, retirement contributions)

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Include overhead percentage (workspace, equipment, admin support)

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Specify number of employees to calculate total team cost

useCases.title: Hiring Budgeting
useCases.description: Calculate true cost of new hires beyond just salary to budget accurately for expansion.

useCases.title: Outsourcing Comparison
useCases.description: Compare total in-house employee cost to contractor or outsourcing rates for fair comparison.

useCases.title: Project Costing
useCases.description: Determine labor component of project costs using fully-loaded employee rates.

useCases.title: Pricing Services
useCases.description: Calculate minimum billable rates that cover fully-loaded labor costs plus profit margin.

seoTips: Benefits typically add 25-40% to base wages - use at least 25% in calculations
Don't forget employer portion of payroll taxes (7.65% Social Security/Medicare)
Overhead includes workspace, equipment, software, insurance, and management time
Billable rates should be 2-3x fully-loaded labor cost for profitable services
Track actual labor costs vs estimates to improve future budgeting accuracy

commonMistakes.title: Using Only Base Wages
commonMistakes.description: Base wage is just the start. Add benefits (25-40%), payroll taxes (7.65%+), and overhead (10-30%) for true cost.

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting Non-Productive Time
commonMistakes.description: Employees don't produce for 100% of paid hours. Account for meetings, training, sick time, and administrative tasks.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Turnover Costs
commonMistakes.description: Hiring and training costs average 50-200% of annual salary. Factor this into long-term labor cost planning.

commonMistakes.title: Not Including All Benefits
commonMistakes.description: Include healthcare, retirement match, PTO, disability, life insurance, and all employer-paid benefits.

faqs.question: What is a fully-loaded labor cost?
faqs.answer: Base wages plus all employer costs: benefits, payroll taxes, workers comp, overhead, and any other costs to employ someone. Typically 1.25-1.5x base wage.

faqs.question: What benefits should I include?
faqs.answer: Health insurance (employer portion), 401k match, PTO value, disability, life insurance, and any other employer-paid benefits.

faqs.question: What overhead should I include?
faqs.answer: Workspace, equipment, software/tools, utilities, HR costs, management time, training, and administrative support.

faqs.question: How do I calculate effective hourly rate?
faqs.answer: Divide annual fully-loaded cost by actual productive hours (typically 1,700-1,900 hours after vacation, sick time, and meetings).

faqs.question: How does this compare to contractors?
faqs.answer: Contractors include their own benefits/overhead in rates. Compare contractor rates to fully-loaded employee cost, not base salary, for fair comparison.
